>>One argument in favor of SOAP is that the java toolkits, client and
>server,
>>are pretty good, while with RESTful HTTP, the server toolkits are pretty
>>good while clients aren't so much.
>>
>>Do y'all buy this argument? Can anyone recommend a very good HTTP client
>>for RESTful application development in java?
>>
>I don't know if I buy this or not.  What is it about Java client tools 
>that is lacking from a REST perspective?

well, availability/stability for one... :) seriously, you've got, what,
three basic choices?

1. java.net.URL and java.net.URLConnection, which barely qualifies as
usable

2. http://www.innovation.ch/java/HTTPClient/ which isn't actively
maintained

3. http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/httpclient/ which is stuck in
perpetual alpha

I would think if you were looking to develop a REST client application,
you'd want a client toolkit that made some things easy on you - simple
things like setting a base URL for a series of requests, easy
authentication... maybe more complex things like associating expected
response codes / response message formats to requests with callback methods
for success or failure. I don't know, I'm in pure speculation mode here,
never having written a non-browser-based REST client, but I guess I don't
see anything in the Java side of things at least that compares favorably
with the RPC toolkits.

Certainly any and all of those could be built on top of the existing http
clients. I guess I'm asking if anyone's aware of anything good that _has_
been written already. If not, why not, and what would a good toolkit look
like?

- donald
